articles.headline: Garland Appoints Weiss as Special Counsel in Hunter Biden Inquiry
articles.snippet: The attorney general said he decided to elevate David C. Weiss after the prosecutor informed him that the powers of a special counsel were necessary to continue the investigation.
articles.abstract: The attorney general said he decided to elevate David C. Weiss after the prosecutor informed him that the powers of a special counsel were necessary to continue the investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Friday elevated the federal prosecutor investigating President Biden’s son Hunter to the status of special counsel after negotiations to revive a plea agreement on tax and gun charges foundered.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Judge Limits Trump’s Ability to Share Jan. 6 Evidence
articles.snippet: During a 90-minute hearing in Washington, Judge Tanya S. Chutkan also warned the former president against any attempt to intimidate witnesses or prejudice potential jurors.
articles.abstract: During a 90-minute hearing in Washington, Judge Tanya S. Chutkan also warned the former president against any attempt to intimidate witnesses or prejudice potential jurors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s prosecution on charges of seeking to overturn the 2020 election rejected his request on Friday to be able to speak broadly about evidence and witnesses — and warned Mr. Trump she would take necessary “measures” to keep him from intimidating witnesses or tainting potential jurors.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Sent to Jail After Judge Revokes Bail
articles.snippet: Mr. Bankman-Fried had been under house arrest at his parents’ home as he awaited trial on charges stemming from the collapse of his cryptocurrency company, FTX.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried had been under house arrest at his parents’ home as he awaited trial on charges stemming from the collapse of his cryptocurrency company, FTX.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, was sent to jail on Friday after a federal judge in New York revoked his bail, accusing him of trying to influence witnesses who are poised to testify against him at a widely anticipated trial in less than two months.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Fox’s Chief Legal Officer Will Depart
articles.snippet: Viet Dinh, an influential force inside the company, advised it through its $787.5 million settlement with Dominion Voting Systems.
articles.abstract: Viet Dinh, an influential force inside the company, advised it through its $787.5 million settlement with Dominion Voting Systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox Corporation’s chief legal officer, Viet Dinh, will depart at the end of the year, in a major shake-up at the company after the landmark $787.5 million settlement it paid to Dominion Voting Systems in April.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: A Journey Through Lahaina’s Endless Streets of Suffering
articles.snippet: A historic Hawaiian town that was once home to 13,000 people is now a desolate ruin. With the death toll rising, the true scope of the tragedy is still unfolding.
articles.abstract: A historic Hawaiian town that was once home to 13,000 people is now a desolate ruin. With the death toll rising, the true scope of the tragedy is still unfolding.
articles.lead_paragraph: Along the empty streets of Lahaina, the warped shells of vehicles sit as if frozen in time, some of them still in the middle of the road, pointed toward escapes that were cut short. Others stand in driveways next to houses that are now piles of ash, many still smoldering with acrid smoke.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker and Philip Cheung

articles.headline: For President Biden, a Political Liability That May Not Go Away Soon
articles.snippet: The collapse of a plea deal and the appointment of a special counsel to investigate Hunter Biden mean the president could face political fallout for months to come.
articles.abstract: The collapse of a plea deal and the appointment of a special counsel to investigate Hunter Biden mean the president could face political fallout for months to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: They thought it was over, that they could put it in the rearview mirror. All that Hunter Biden had to do was show up in a courtroom, answer a few questions, sign some paperwork and that would be it. Not that the Republicans would let it go, but any real danger would be past.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker

articles.headline: Move or Quit: Grindr Dictates New Office Rules Amid Union Drive
articles.snippet: Two weeks after employees filed to organize, the company told some they had to change cities or would lose their jobs. It said the plan had long been in the works.
articles.abstract: Two weeks after employees filed to organize, the company told some they had to change cities or would lose their jobs. It said the plan had long been in the works.
articles.lead_paragraph: Quinn McGee learned last week that to keep their job as a product manager at Grindr, the gay dating app, they would have to move to California from New York by October under the company’s new return-to-office rules.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg

articles.headline: The Iowa State Fair Saw Many G.O.P. Candidates but Only One Trump
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump asserted his dominance in Iowa on Saturday as he squared off against his closest rival, Ron DeSantis, in the Super Bowl of retail politics.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump asserted his dominance in Iowa on Saturday as he squared off against his closest rival, Ron DeSantis, in the Super Bowl of retail politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: The crowd cheered. The pork was charred. And then someone shouted at former President Donald J. Trump, asking him to identify his biggest challenger in the 2024 Republican primary.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: As Hollywood Strikes Roll On, Viewers Have a Chance to Catch Up
articles.snippet: After years of being inundated with new shows, some are using a pause in production to finally watch all the stuff they missed when it came out.
articles.abstract: After years of being inundated with new shows, some are using a pause in production to finally watch all the stuff they missed when it came out.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Hollywood’s labor disputes grinding on, and virtually all production stopped, anxiety began creeping into Zain Habboo’s house in Chevy Chase, Md.
articles.byline: By John Koblin

articles.headline: Inexpensive Add-on Spawns a New Era of Machine Guns
articles.snippet: Popular devices known as “switches” are turning ordinary pistols into fully automatic weapons, making them deadlier and a growing threat to bystanders.
articles.abstract: Popular devices known as “switches” are turning ordinary pistols into fully automatic weapons, making them deadlier and a growing threat to bystanders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Caison Robinson, 14, had just met up with a younger neighbor on their quiet street after finishing his chores when a gunman in a white car rolled up and fired a torrent of bullets in an instant.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Growing Segregation by Sex in Israel Raises Fears for Women’s Rights
articles.snippet: Ultra-Orthodox members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right coalition want to expand the powers of all-male rabbinical courts, and to bar women and men from mixing in many public arenas.
articles.abstract: Ultra-Orthodox members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right coalition want to expand the powers of all-male rabbinical courts, and to bar women and men from mixing in many public arenas.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trains from Tel Aviv were packed one evening last month when Inbal Boxerman, a 40-year-old mother of two, was blocked by a wall of men as she tried to board. One of them told her that women were not allowed on — the car was for men only.
articles.byline: By Roni Caryn Rabin

articles.headline: Zelensky Called Him a Criminal. Now Ukraine Calls Him for Guns and Ammo.
articles.snippet: In its hunt for weapons, Ukraine has rolled back anticorruption rules and turned to people once seen as relics of an anything-goes era.
articles.abstract: In its hunt for weapons, Ukraine has rolled back anticorruption rules and turned to people once seen as relics of an anything-goes era.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early weeks of the war in Ukraine, with the invading Russian Army bearing down on Kyiv, the Ukrainian government needed weapons, and quickly. So its Ministry of Defense made a desperate and unlikely phone call.
articles.byline: By Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Letter to a Young Crypto Enthusiast (or the Merely Curious)
articles.snippet: An ever-growing number of young people, males in particular, have bought cryptocurrencies. Here’s some advice, without the finger-wagging.
articles.abstract: An ever-growing number of young people, males in particular, have bought cryptocurrencies. Here’s some advice, without the finger-wagging.
articles.lead_paragraph: You were right. It’s not a passing fad.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Would F-16s Have Made the Difference in Ukraine’s Counteroffensive?
articles.snippet: Most military experts doubt that they would have, and say that Kyiv can still prevail without them.
articles.abstract: Most military experts doubt that they would have, and say that Kyiv can still prevail without them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s counteroffensive began two months ago, but in many ways its forces have been preparing for it for years by learning how to fight like NATO militaries, with a mix of infantry, artillery, armored vehicles and air power.
articles.byline: By Lara Jakes

articles.headline: How Trump Benefits From an Indictment Effect
articles.snippet: In polling, fund-raising and conservative media, the former president has turned criminal charges into political assets.
articles.abstract: In polling, fund-raising and conservative media, the former president has turned criminal charges into political assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early on March 18, former President Donald J. Trump hit send on a social media post saying he would be “arrested on Tuesday of next week.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Ruth Igielnik, Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The Dream Was Universal Access to Knowledge. The Result Was a Fiasco.
articles.snippet: In the pandemic emergency, Brewster Kahle’s Internet Archive freely lent out digital scans of its library. Publishers sued. Owning a book means something different now.
articles.abstract: In the pandemic emergency, Brewster Kahle’s Internet Archive freely lent out digital scans of its library. Publishers sued. Owning a book means something different now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Information wants to be free. That observation, first made in 1984, anticipated the internet and the world to come. It cost nothing to digitally reproduce data and words, and so we have them in numbing abundance.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Raid of Small Kansas Newspaper Raises Free Press Concerns
articles.snippet: The search of The Marion County Record’s office led to the seizure of computers, servers and cellphones of reporters and editors.
articles.abstract: The search of The Marion County Record’s office led to the seizure of computers, servers and cellphones of reporters and editors.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small town in Kansas has become a battleground over the First Amendment, after the local police force and county sheriff’s deputies raided the office of The Marion County Record.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: As Inferno Grew, Lahaina’s Water System Collapsed
articles.snippet: Firefighters who rushed to contain the Maui wildfire found that hydrants were running dry, forcing crews to embark instead on a perilous rescue mission.
articles.abstract: Firefighters who rushed to contain the Maui wildfire found that hydrants were running dry, forcing crews to embark instead on a perilous rescue mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the frantic moments on Tuesday after a wildfire jumped containment near a residential neighborhood in Lahaina, Hawaii, firefighters rushing to slow the spread were distressed to find that their hydrants were starting to run dry.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Kellen Browning and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: When Tragedy Strikes in China, the Government Cracks Down on Grief
articles.snippet: The Chinese government represses public grief, withholding information and stanching displays of mourning to tell history the way it wants it told.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government represses public grief, withholding information and stanching displays of mourning to tell history the way it wants it told.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many innocent lives were lost to tragic events in China in the past month. So far we haven’t learned a single name of any of them from China’s government or its official media. Nor have we seen news interviews of family members talking about their loved ones.
articles.byline: By Li Yuan

articles.headline: Two Months in Georgia: How Trump Tried to Overturn the Vote
articles.snippet: The Georgia case offers a vivid reminder of the extraordinary lengths Mr. Trump and his allies went to in the Southern state to reverse the election.
articles.abstract: The Georgia case offers a vivid reminder of the extraordinary lengths Mr. Trump and his allies went to in the Southern state to reverse the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Donald Trump’s expected surrender at a jail in Georgia.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Taliban Fighters, Unsettled by Peace, Seek New Battles Abroad
articles.snippet: Two years on from when the Taliban took Kabul, the outflow of young Talibs has renewed fears of violent extremism spilling across Afghanistan’s borders.
articles.abstract: Two years on from when the Taliban took Kabul, the outflow of young Talibs has renewed fears of violent extremism spilling across Afghanistan’s borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a child studying in a madrasa in Afghanistan, Mohammad Khalid Tahir dreamed of waging jihad. By the time he was a teenager, he had joined the Taliban and celebrated when they seized power from the U.S.-backed government two years ago.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Jim Huylebroek

articles.headline: ‘We Are Not Human to Them’: Life for Convicts in Russia’s Army
articles.snippet: In an account provided to The Times, a Russian soldier describes his commanders’ casual disregard for the lives of inmates like him, and how they are pressured to re-enlist.
articles.abstract: In an account provided to The Times, a Russian soldier describes his commanders’ casual disregard for the lives of inmates like him, and how they are pressured to re-enlist.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a month spent at the front line, Aleksandr, an ex-convict serving in the Russian Army, hadn’t seen a single Ukrainian soldier and had barely fired a shot. The threat of death came from a distance, and seemingly from everywhere.
articles.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ekaterina Bodyagina

articles.headline: CNN Overhauls Programming Lineup, Aiming to Lift Ratings
articles.snippet: Abby Phillip, host of “Inside Politics Sunday,” will be the new anchor of CNN’s 10 p.m. hour on weekdays.
articles.abstract: Abby Phillip, host of “Inside Politics Sunday,” will be the new anchor of CNN’s 10 p.m. hour on weekdays.
articles.lead_paragraph: CNN, which has battled sagging ratings this year, on Monday unveiled a substantial remaking of its morning and evening programming.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: In Retail’s Top Echelons, Female C.E.O.s Lose a Bit of Ground
articles.snippet: Several prominent companies, like the Gap and Kohl’s, have recently replaced female leaders with men. Industry observers see a loss in gender representation.
articles.abstract: Several prominent companies, like the Gap and Kohl’s, have recently replaced female leaders with men. Industry observers see a loss in gender representation.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the start of this year, a slew of major retailers were searching for the right person to fill their chief executive roles. Most of those companies have now found that person — and in almost every case it was a man.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman
